title: 115_s1862
content: The Act may be cited as the "Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2017". Section 103 of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include a definition of "concrete actions" as efforts by a country's government to combat trafficking, such as enforcement actions, investigations, prosecutions, convictions, training, programs, partnerships, and prevention efforts. The amended Section 103 of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 defines "concrete actions" as government efforts to combat trafficking, including prevention programs, victim services like immigration assistance and restitution, and financial commitments to these actions. Credible information includes reports from the Department of State and other federal agencies. The amended Section 103 of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 defines "concrete actions" as government efforts to combat trafficking, including prevention programs, victim services, and financial commitments. Reports from federal agencies, foreign countries' documentation, civil society materials, and information from survivors are considered in evaluating these efforts. The amended Section 103 of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 defines "concrete actions" as government efforts to combat trafficking, including prevention programs, victim services, financial commitments, information from survivors, media reports, academic reports, and assessments of impact. The sense of Congress is that the private sector should support law enforcement agencies in combating child sex trafficking through technology and that private businesses should actively work to prevent and combat this crime. Additionally, Congress believes that any future funding for anti-trafficking programs should include accountability measures. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION ON PLACEMENT OR RECRUITMENT FEES. Section 106(g) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to redesignate clauses and subparagraphs, making adjustments to placement and recruitment fees regulations. Section 106(g) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include regulations on placement or recruitment fees. SEC. 5 amends the Trafficking Victims Protection Act to include enabling trafficking in addition to condoning it. SEC. 6 addresses actions against governments that do not meet minimum standards. Section 110(b) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to require the report to cover efforts and activities between April 1 of the previous year and March 31 of the reporting year, based only on concrete actions taken by the country. The amendment to Section 110(b) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 requires the report to include details of concrete actions taken by countries during the reporting period, including explanations for changes in country listings and their contributions to such changes. The amendment to Section 110(b) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 requires countries to report on actions taken to meet minimum standards, with specific changes in reporting deadlines and requirements. The amendment to Section 110(b) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 now requires countries to report detailed information supporting their determination on a public website and offer briefings to relevant committees on any written plans submitted. The amendment to Section 110(b) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 now requires countries to report detailed information supporting their determination on a public website and offer briefings to relevant committees on any written plans submitted. Additionally, countries must provide information on budgetary resources allocated for investigating, prosecuting, convicting, sentencing, and obtaining restitution for victims of human trafficking. The amendment to Section 110(b) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 now requires countries to report detailed information supporting their determination on a public website and offer briefings to relevant committees on any written plans submitted. Countries must also allocate sufficient budgetary resources to protect and support victims of trafficking, prevent trafficking, and consult with civil society organizations to improve services for victims. Additionally, countries upgraded to tier 2 watchlist must develop action plans within 180 days of the annual Trafficking in Persons report. The annual Trafficking in Persons Report now requires countries upgraded from Tier 3 to Tier 2 Watchlist to prepare and present action plans to improve their tier ranking. The government of each country must prepare action plans to address deficiencies preventing them from meeting Tier 2 standards. The plans should focus on short-term and multi-year goals. Ambassadors and regional Assistant Secretaries will brief the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on these plans. The Senate and House committees oversee the implementation of action plans to address trafficking issues. The paragraph does not modify minimum standards or actions against governments failing to meet them. SEC. 7. COMMUNICATION WITH GOVERNMENTS OF TIER 2 WATCH LIST COUNTRIES ON TRAFFICKING IN PERSONS REPORT. The Secretary of State must annually provide Tier 2 Watch List countries with the Trafficking in Persons report and information on their downgrade, including confirmation, implications, contributing factors, and necessary steps for improvement. The Secretary of State must communicate downgrade information to Tier 2 Watch List countries, including steps for improvement. SEC. 8. US SUPPORT FOR ANTI-TRAFFICKING IN MULTILATERAL DEVELOPMENT BANKS. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of State, shall instruct the United States Executive Director of each multilateral development bank to develop anti-human trafficking provisions, require risk assessments, and support analyses of trafficking impact on economic and social indicators. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Secretary of State, instructs multilateral development banks to integrate anti-trafficking interventions into projects, increase capacity for human trafficking risk assessments, and develop policies to reduce trafficking prevalence. The Secretary of the Treasury is directed to integrate anti-trafficking interventions into projects and increase capacity for human trafficking risk assessments. Relevant officials will brief key Senate and House committees on the implementation of these measures. The Senate passed S. 1862 on December 17, 2018, amending the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 to revise criteria for determining countries' compliance with human trafficking standards.
